member.name: T:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.Arguments
member.summary: Arguments for an RPC notification or request.
member.remarks: Arguments are represented as one of: - An array of positional arguments - A dictionary of named arguments - An EventArgs object with properties that are named arguments

member.name: M:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.Arguments.Resolve(System.Reflection.ParameterInfo[],System.Object[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Matches arguments to a list of method parameters, based on the argument positions, names, and/or types.
member.param: Reflected method parameters
Arguments array to be filled in by the resolution.
Count of arguments to resolve. May be less than the length of parmaeters if final parameter(s) are handled separately.
member.returns: True if the arguments were successfully resolved, or false if the arguments are invalid (in number or type) for the specified parameters.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.Arguments.Resolve``1
member.summary: Matches named arguments to an EventArgs type.
member.returns: Resolved EventArgs instance, or null if the arguments are invalid for the specified EventArgs type.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.Arguments.Resolve(System.Type)
member.summary: Matches named arguments to an EventArgs type.
member.param: EventArgs subclass
member.returns: Resolved EventArgs instance, or null if the arguments are invalid for the specified EventArgs type.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.IRpcClient
member.summary: Represents a generic RPC client capable of creating RPC sessions.
member.remarks: The recommended usage pattern is to call once first and then call in order to create an RPC session associated with the connection.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.IRpcClient.ConnectAsync(System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Establishes an RPC connection and initializes internal state.
member.param: The cancellation token.
member.remarks: It's mandatory to call this method before trying to create an RPC session.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.IRpcClient.CreateSessionAsync(System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Creates a new RPC session for the current connection.
member.param: A cancellation token.
member.exception: Thrown if the client instance is not connected.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.IRpcClient.ReconnectToSessionAsync(Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.IRpcSession,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Reconnects this client to a given rpc session.
member.param: The rpc session to connect to.
Cancellation token.
member.returns: True if reconnect succeeded, false if the host declined the reconnect request.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.IRpcFilter
member.summary: An RPC filter gets a chance to modify RPC messages immediately before they are sent or after they are received.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.IRpcFilter.FilterNotification(Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.NotificationMessage,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Filters a notification message before sending or after receiving.
member.param: The notification message being sent or received.
True if the notification is about to be sent; false if the notification was just received.
member.returns: The notification message, potentially modified, or null to suppress the notification.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.IRpcFilter.FilterRequest(Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.RequestMessage,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Filters a request message before sending or after receiving.
member.param: The request message being sent or received.
True if the request is about to be sent; false if the request was just received.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.IRpcFilter.FilterResponse(Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.RequestMessage,Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.ResponseMessage,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Filters a response message before sending or after receiving.
member.param: The request message that generated the response.
The response message being sent or received.
True if the response is about to be sent; false if the response was just received.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.IRpcService
member.summary: Defines a service that can be registered for use with an RpcSession.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.IRpcService.Name
member.summary: Name of the service. In JSON-RPC requests, notification and request method names are prefixed with the service name (delimited with a period).

member.name: M:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.IRpcService.HandleNotification(Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.NotificationMessage)
member.summary: Receives a notification from the RPC client.
member.remarks: Notifications cannot be cancelled by the caller. An implementation of this method should avoid a significant synchronous delay.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.IRpcService.HandleRequestAsync(Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.RequestMessage,System.IProgress{Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.ProgressMessage},System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Receives a request from the RPC client, and returns a response object.
member.remarks: Requests can be cancelled by the caller; request handlers should respond to cancellations via the cancellation token. An implementation of this method should avoid a significant synchronous delay, though any amount of delay is allowed before returning the asynchronous result.

member.name: E:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.IRpcService.Notify
member.summary: Sends notifications to the RPC client.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.IRpcService.Trace
member.summary: Gets a trace source that is used to trace messages related to this service.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.IRpcSession
member.summary: Interface for an RPC session - enables a session to be mocked for testing.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.IRpcSession.StreamTransport
member.summary: Gets or sets stream transport service that allows direct stream connection over the rpc session, or null if there is no such transport.
member.remarks: This property is initially null for a new session, and should be set to IRpcStreamTransport once, before RPC services use this session. Changing this property after that may cause undetermined behavior. It is dependent on the underlying transport like ssh; the RPC library doesn't set or use it. It is merely a convenient way to associate stream transport with a session.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.IRpcSession.Principal
member.summary: Gets or sets a principal containing claims about the user or server on the other end of the session, or null if the session is not authenticated.
member.remarks:
This property is initially null for an unauthenticated session, and should be set to a ClaimsPrincipal instance after successful client or server authentication.
The set of claims is application-dependent; the RPC library does not use the claims. The property is merely a convenient way to associate authentication results with a session.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.IRpcSession.EnableReconnection
member.summary: Enables reconnection on this session. If the session doesn't reconnect in 1 min time delay, the session is disposed.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.IRpcSession.Filter
member.summary: Gets or sets RPC message filter. The filter, if not null, will be applied to: * Requests and notifications before sending them to the RPC stream. * Responses read from from the RPC stream. Filter can be changed when the session is running. Filter used for a request will also be used for the response for that request.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.IRpcSession.SendRequestAsync(Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.RequestMessage,System.Diagnostics.TraceSource,System.Threading.CancellationToken,System.IProgress{Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.ProgressMessage},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sends a request and waits asynchronously for a response.
member.param: RPC request message
Trace source for the request and response message
Token for cancelling the request
Optional progress object for receiving progress notifications while the request is processing.
True if the RPC session should be closed immediately after the response to this request is received (before trying to reading any more bytes from the stream).
member.remarks: The finalRequest parameter allows closing the session without having to cancel a pending read operation, which can be problematic for some kinds of streams (WebSocket / Azure Relay).

member.name: P:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.IRpcSessionClient.Session
member.summary: Active RPC session

member.summary: Event args for the event that stream transport fires when a stream opens

member.summary: Stream id

member.summary: Stream over the RPC session

member.name: P:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.StreamOpeningEventArgs.IsAuthorized
member.summary: A value indicating whether the handler authorizes opening of the stream. If set to true by the handler, OpenStreamAsync will succeed, and the handler must assume the ownership of Stream and use it to communicate with the other party.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.ResponseMessage
member.summary: Response message for a JSON-RPC request.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.ResponseMessage.HandlingTimes
member.summary: Array of times in milliseconds taken to send/receive/respond to requests
member.remarks:
Includes times from sending requests to receiving responses and time from receiving requests to returning responses.
E.g. a simple scenario where A makes a request to B: A sends a request to B and begins timing. B receives the request and begins timing. B processes the request. B is ready to resolve the request, so stops timing, stamps the time it took to respond on the response message, and sends the reponse. A receives the response, stops timing, subtracts off the time taken for B to respond (this time is included in the response message) and adds another item to the list of handling times on the response message. The first time in the list of handling times is the amount of time it took B to process the request, and the second time in the list is the communication latency between A and B.
In more complicated scenarios where requests go through multiple clients, the list of handling times can be used to find the communication latency between each RPC client in the chain, and how long processing took at each client.
In general, the last client in the chain will only contribute one time to the list: the amount of time it took to respond to the request. So this is always the first item in the list. Similarly, the first client in the chain (the one that made the initial request) only contributes one time to the list: the communication latency between itself and the first client in the chain. So this is always the last item in the list. Intermediate clients contribute 2 times each: the first is the communication latency between the client and the next in the chain. The second is the time it took the client to do any intermediate processing before forwarding the request on to the next client and returning the response to the previous client.
E.g. if HandlingTimes = [a, b, c, d], there were three clients involved in the request. a is the time it took the last client to handle the request, b is the communication latency between the second and third client, c is the time it took the second client from receiving the request from the first client to forward the request to the third client plus the time from receiving the response from the third client to sending it to the first client, and d is the communication latency between the first and second client. The full time from the first client making the request to receiving the response is a + b + c + d. In general, the latency of the request is the sum of every other item in the list, starting at index 1 (here b + d), and the processing time is the sum of every other item in the list, starting at index 0 (here a + c).

member.name: T:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.ProgressAction`1
member.summary: Basic implementation of the interface.
member.remarks: .NET's class runs the actions on a background thread, which means they may get handled out of order or after the operation finishes. That may be good for some scenarios, but it's probably unexpected with working with RPC. So this class may be used instead.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.RemoteException
member.summary: Relays details about an unhandled exception thrown by the remote handler of an RPC request.

members.member: Arguments for an event raised when an RPC session disconnects, either due to a direct call to or because the underlying stream disconnected.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.RpcDisconnectedEventArgs.Message
member.summary: Message describing the reason for disconnection.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.RpcDisconnectedEventArgs.Exception
member.summary: Optional exception that was the cause of the disconnection.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.RpcDisconnectedEventArgs.EnableReconnect
member.summary: An event-handler may set this property to `true` to prevent disposal of the sesssion and enable it to be reconnected at a later time.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.RpcDisconnectedException
member.summary: Exception thrown by RPC send request when it cannot do that because either there was a stream error writing the request message, or the stream has been closed before the response has arrived. This can be thrown in two cases: 1. When RPC cannot write a request message and closes the session because of that. In this case InnerException will have the exception occured during writing. 2. When the session is disconnected, either explicitly, or due to some error.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.RpcDispatcher`1
member.summary: Uses reflection to dispatch incoming notifications and requests to the appropriate service method, and send outgoing notifications in response to events raised by the service.
member.typeparam: Interface that defines the RPC service methods and notification events.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.RpcDispatcher`1.#ctor(System.String,`0,System.Diagnostics.TraceSource)
member.summary: Creates a new dispatcher for a service.
member.param: Registered name of the service.
Implementation of the service interface.
member.remarks: In addition to implementing the service interface methods raising interface events, services that wish to RECEIVE events (notifications) via the dispatcher must implement methods of the form: void OnEventName(object sender, EventArgsType e) where `EventName` is the name of the RPC notification, as declared by the contract, and `EventArgsType` is the type of event args declared by the contract.

member.summary: Gets message conext of the active RPC request or an empty dictionary.

member.summary: Event raised when the session disconnects, either due to a direct call to or because the underlying stream disconnected.

member.name: E:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.RpcSession.RpcRequestHandled
member.summary: Event fired when an RPC request is handled.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.RpcSession.Disconnect(System.String,System.Exception)
member.summary: Disconnects the session and disposes the underlying stream.
member.param: Message describing the reason for disconnection.
Optional exception that was the cause of the disconnection.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.RpcSession.Dispose
member.summary: Disposes the RPC session and disconnects from the stream. Any processing of inbound requests is cancelled, and any pending outbound requests fail with an .

member.name: M:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.RpcSession.Connect(Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.IRpcStream)
member.summary: Connects or RE-connects the RPC session to a stream.
member.remarks: Re-connection enables an RPC session to be resumed without losing all the state (RPC services and pending requests) on one side or both sides. To enable re-connection, handle the event and set the flag to true on one side or both sides of the session. That prevents the RPC session from being disposed by the disconnect, and retains the registration of services. Additionally, any RPC requests that were pending / incomplete at the time of the disconnect will automatically be re-sent upon reconnection.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.RpcSessionPurpose
member.summary: Who hosts RPC server, handles RPC requests, and who may be the RPC client.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.RpcSessionPurpose.ClientToAgent
member.summary: RPC between the client and the agent, the agent is the server. RPC starts when the client loads Live Share on startup and it then starts the agent.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.RpcSessionPurpose.GuestToHostClient
member.summary: RPC between the host and a guest, the host client is the server. The host agent just forwards RPC through to the client. RPC starts when a guest connects.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Cascade.Rpc.RpcSessionPurpose.GuestToHostAgent
member.summary: RPC between the host and a guest, the host agent is the server. RPC starts when a guest connects.
